intro: You are assisting Mr McLeod, a resident who has been feeling fatigued and unsteady on his feet. He is reluctant to go for a walk outside due to tiredness and worries about falling. Use empathetic communication to encourage him to change into safer footwear and use his walking stick, while ensuring he feels supported and reassured about his safety.
description_html:
This scenario focuses on supporting safe mobility for a stroke survivor with left-sided weakness. You will practice assessing mobility needs and providing appropriate support.

Learning objectives:

  • Check for safe footwear before mobilizing
  • Ensure walking aids are available and used correctly
  • Support on the weaker side during walking
  • Recognize stroke-related mobility limitations
  • Encourage independence within safe limits

resident.name: Mr McLeod
goals: agree to short walk after encouragement
agree to change footwear to non-slip shoes
acknowledge walking stick needed but misplaced
disclose weaker left side due to previous stroke
signal readiness to walk after reassurance
must_disclose: finds it difficult to rise from chair
refusals: initially reluctant to walk due to fatigue

safety.if_red_flag_then: carer must pause, adjust environment (footwear, aid), and provide reassurance before proceeding

actions.title: Help to stand
actions.prompt: You offer your arm and help Mr McLeod rise carefully from his chair.

actions.title: Change footwear
actions.prompt: You help Mr McLeod change from his slippers into his non-slip shoes to ensure his safety.

actions.title: Retrieve walking stick
actions.prompt: You pick up Mr McLeod's walking stick from the floor and hand it to him.

actions.title: Walk to garden
actions.prompt: You and Mr McLeod walk together to the garden area, taking it slowly and watching for any signs of unsteadiness.
